Here I am exploring the assumptions behind my and the Crowd’s forecasts. A lot of the people I follow are forecasting >90% for “no” such as @Tetbury @Anneinak @cdob63 @Wildwood2000 @WBHumanoid @Hammer-Time. However, Johnson will stay PM only if Conservatives win a majority, which Electoral calculus puts at 64% currently.  One justification for this discrepancy is that even if Tories don’t get a majority, it will take some time for a new PM to be selected, which could take us beyond Dec 31. For example, if Tories get the largest minority they will take a crack at forming a government and negotiations with the Scottish party and the Lib Dems will follow. Or if Labour is given the chance to form a government, then it will have to negotiate with the same parties which will take some time as well. But how high is the probability for that? If we assume a 36% chance that the Tories don’t get majority, then the probability that the process to select new PM will finish by Dec 31 would have to be 27% or lower for the final probability of a “no” resolution to be 90% or more ((1-0.9)/0.36 = 0.27). 27% seems justifiable but could also be considered a little low. If the chances for a Tory majority drop much further that would justify moving below 90% on “No” here.

Copying over my rationale from my "Will a political party gain an overall majority of seats in the House of Commons at the next UK General Election?" prediction: The polls started since November 12th listed on Wikipedia ( https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_2019_United_Kingdom_general_election ), run through the Electoral Calculus ( https://www.electoralcalculus.co.uk/userpoll.html ) and UK Swingometer ( http://www.electionpolling.co.uk/swingometer/uk-parliament ) sites to estimate seat results. YouGov, Nov 12-20: Conservative majority 104, Conservative majority 80.
The Telegraph, Nov 18-19: Conservative majority 66, Conservative majority 50.
The Times, Nov 18-19: Conservative majority 62, Conservative majority 62.
Evening Standard, Nov 15-19: Conservative majority 152, Conservative majority 108.
ICM Resarch, Nov 15-18: Conservative majority 50, Conservative majority 44.
Kantar, Nov 14-18: Conservative majority 204, Conservative majority 122.
Survation, Nov 14-16: Conservative majority 100, Conservative majority 82.
The Mail, Nov 14-16: Conservative majority 136, Conservative majority 106.
The Times, Nov 14-15: Conservative majority 164, Conservative majority 120.
The Observer, Nov 13-15: Conservative majority 142, Conservative majority 110.
The Independent, Nov 12-15: Conservative majority 8, Conservative majority 6.
The Telegraph, Nov 13-14: Conservative majority 20, Conservative majority 24.
Panelbase, Nov 13-14: Conservative majority 88, Conservative majority 70. And the average from the the FT poll tracker ( https://www.ft.com/content/263615ca-d873-11e9-8f9b-77216ebe1f17 ) run through those same two sites predicts a Conservative majority of 84 / 70. Analysis: In the raw popular support, the Conservatives seem to be averaging the same overall support that they had on polling day in 2017; all the polls (except the Independent's) have them within the margin of error on the 43.43% they got that year. Labour support, however, is way down, with the Liberal Democrats way up. The Brexit Party seems to be polling ahead of UKIP's 2017 results, though it's small enough that polling errors might be an issue. It is notable that many polls are only polling Brexit Party in constituencies where it's running, which is substantially fewer constituencies than UKIP was running in in 2017. So, there are perhaps two paths to Labour managing to recover. The first is Johnson making a serious blunder like May did on long-term care and scaring voters currently voting their Brexit preference into swapping to a "Stop the Tories" vote. The problem with that is that everybody remembers what happened to May, and is presumably going to do his best to avoid that. The second is anti-Brexit voters currently supporting the LibDem/Green/Cymru alliance looking at a Conservative majority and deciding they prefer Labour's wishy-washiness to Johnson being able to push through his deal. The problem with the second is that a good deal of the anti-Brexit coalition is from a "Brexit is bad for business" perspective, and neither Corbyn's comments on the sort of Brexit he wants nor his new back-to-the-Seventies Labour manifesto do anything but push that sort of voter away from Labour.

Johnson has hitched his wagon to Finance Capital, and to the US, both of which funded his PM campaign and installed him in office. He has little support from Manufacturing and Services Capital as they stand to lose bigtime with any but the softest Brexit. Pro-EU Conservatives and EU-associated corporations will not support his "do or die" approach to Brexit. Corbyn's approach, to put aside the Brexit Spectacle and concentrate on practical socio-economic and political issues, may work with the electorate, but the Labour Party has an uphill struggle against an overwhelmingly pro-Tory media and the Brexit Spectacle. Even if Labour succeeds and gains seats, as in 2017, demographics mean that it will never again form a majority government.  Thus the only two results I can foresee are:  a) a Tory minority government
b) a 'progressive alliance' of non-Tory parties If (a), Johnson's position is touch and go, and anti-Brexit Tories may demand his head as the price for propping up a Tory government. If (b), the LibDems have already ruled out supporting Corbyn as PM, Labour will never support Swinson as a LibDem PM, so it's possible that a compromise candidate such as a centrist Labour MP (eg Starmer) or the highly-regarded Green Caroline Lucas, may emerge.

So far BJ and the conservatives have been quite successful in framing this as the people v parliament election. Re-enforced by the decision of the Supreme Court, the delays to Brexit by parliament by a coalition including many who say they want to stop Brexit. Labours nuanced position is partly caught up in being seen as delaying it and will be difficult for it to pitch against a far simpler “Get Brexit Done”. The split in the leave camp is between the Conservatives and The Brexit Party. Since the summer the Brexit party has gradually seen its support decrease from the high point of the European elections to around 10%-11%, that support has gone to the Conservatives who in the poll of polls are averaging around 34-35%. Key to the Conservatives will be maintaining that position and squeezing the Brexit party support even more. Nigel Farage should not be underestimated however the previous performance of UKIP at elections never fulfilled the promise of expectations of their supporters. The remain camp is split between several parties with labour trying to straddle both camps. Labours average polling on the poll of polls is around 24-25%. With Lib Dem’s around 18%. There is a big issue of how good polling companies are and recent years they have performed poorly not calling the referendum itself and the last election as two examples. So we have to be very careful about putting too much faith in the numbers. There are about 10 weeks before 1st Jan. A GE (according to the BBC) needs a gap of at least 5 weeks between the date it is called and the date it is held because Parliament needs to be closed for 25 working days. A GE will not take place in Christmas week, and  a GE in the week before that would be very unpopular. By my calculation the earliest GE possible if it were called today would be 28th Nov. 
In order to call a GE today parliament would need to vote with 2/3 MPs supporting the plan. This seems very unlikely as that would require Labour to support the plan, and Labour has said they will not support a GE before A50 has been extended. I take this to mean they would not vote for a GE before 1st Nov. (In case BJ managed to somehow cancel any extension offered or the EU failed to offer the extension.) Its also unlikely that Labour would want Parliament closed in the next two or three weeks.) So I think that only leaves the week in which 12 December is in,  which a GE could be fitted in.  Other ways to hold a GE include a Short Bill (where MPs pass a Bill that says the Fixed Term Parliament Act is suspended. That would be easier to pass than the 2/3 of MPs vote, but that would take a few days to pass and then presumably the Opposition Parties would vote against it if the vote was held before 1st Nov. So that would also not get a GE before 12th December. To get that through BJ would need to  be supported by all the Conservatives that he has thrown out of the party and the DUP. I don't see why they would want to help him (the ex-Conservative MPs would lose their seats, the DUP would probably lose seats.) The SNP and LibDems are  keen to get an election, but I doubt that they would want to annoy Labour who they might need voting support from later.)   The No Confidence vote route would not lead to a GE before Jan if Corbyn waits until after 1 Nov to trigger it as the process on this route takes 7 weeks. But that would only happen anyway if Corbyn called No Confidence and then failed in getting made PM. It looks very unlikely that Opposition MPs plus Conservatives who don't like BJ, would call No Confidence in BJ but this appears to be the only way that a Labour PM could happen before 1st Jan.
If a GE did happen it seems very unlikely that Corby would become PM. It would probably give the Conservatives the most seats and might give the Conservatives the majority.

Will there be a general election before 2020? Yes, it seems very likely that there will be a general election (>95%). A general election takes 5 weeks to conduct [1] so there is enough time to hold one before 2020.  All of the major parties (Con, Lab, Lib Dem, SNP) seem to be keen to go ahead with an election once the chance of a 'no deal' Brexit has been mitigated against. As it seems certain that there will be an extension agreed with the EU after the Letwin amendment was passed by parliament this weekend the barriers to a general election seem to have dropped. Will there be legal action that forces the current PM out before 2020? Very unlikely (<5%). It doesn't seem like there is enough evidence for this to happen. So this makes it likely that Boris Johnson will be leading the Conservative Party into the next general election. UK politics do seem to be largely about leaders (my supposition) so the current polling isn't likely to be invalidated soon. Will there be a vote of no confidence in the current PM that replaces him as leader of the Conservative Party? Again, very unlikely (<5%). Boris Johnson was only recently elected by this Conservative Party and won convincingly. Will there be a vote of no-confidence in the current government that creates a stable government able to stay in power beyond late November 2019 (five week lead-in for election)?  It doesn't seem like there is an appetite for this once an extension with the EU has been agreed (<20%). Who would win a general election? Current polling suggests that Conservatives have 35% of the vote and Labour 25% [2]. The last election saw Labour come from a low of 25% 04/04/2017 to 40% of the vote at the election 08/06/2017 [2]. In the same election, the Conservatives won 42.4% of the vote having had around 46% 04/04/2017 (high of 47% 11/05/2017)[2]. Both main parties are bleeding support to the Brexit Party and the Liberal Democrats in a reversal of what happened in the run-up to the 2017 general election (swap Brexit Party for UKIP). Conservative Party has indicated that they will not go into coalition with the Brexit Part [3].
SNP have indicated that they would not enter a coalition with any party but would be willing to enter a confidence & supply agreement if the terms were right. I’m sorry but I can’t find a reference for this.
The Liberal Democrats have said that they won’t support a Labour government under Jeremy Corbyn even in the event of a hung parliament (4). The first past the post system makes it very unlikely that any party other than Labour or Conservative would be able to form a government. In summary, I think there will be a general election and it will essentially be a contest between the incumbant and the Labour Party. Current polling suggests a Conservative win but this picture was similar in the run-up to the last election as well where the end result was only a 2.5% difference between Labour and Conservative. I believe the gap in the polls will narrow in an election campaign but it is likely that the Conservative Party will end up forming a minority government. 1. https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-49004486

For a first forecast I will use two different outside views: Outside view 1: Cameron lasted for 3 weeks after the Brexit referendum and May lasted for 3 years, giving a half-life of 1.5 years for PMs in Brexit conditions. As there remain 2.5 months till the end of the year, this gives a 7% probability of decay. But that depends wildly on how the probability distribution peaks: the probability at the beginning could be lower or higher, so lets say from 4 to 14%. Outside view 2: in this case we ignore Cameron, and take May as the quintessential example of a PM under Brexit conditions. She survived about five crises before resigning: 1 vote of no confidence, 3 defeats for the first version of May's deal, plus a modified version that could not even made it into a vote. However the number of crises could be counted differently depending on the criterion used. Assuming that her resignation was a 50/50 event at the moment it did happen, then if we notice that (1-0.13)^5 = 0.493, this gives a 13% probability of resignation (or being ousted) after a crisis. Resignation only equates a new prime minister with the pass of time, which means that if Boris Johnson resigns at the end of November or later, there will be no new PM till 2020. If it is a vote of no confidence, this could happen faster and the window could extend to mid-December. According to outside view 2, we must find which are the pending crises till the end of November and for each compound a 13% probability of resigning, being kicked out, etc. The only crisis in sight is Super Saturday, 19th of October, and the crisis is not bound to happen as there could be the promise of a deal in sight. If we assume a 50% of a crisis, we end up with a 6.5% of being kicked out, or a 7% after rounding. To this we can add a 3% that Boris decides to resign in order for another person to send the extension letter. Total 10% of resignation. Now notice that both outside view 1 and 2 yield very similar probabilities, indicating that it might be a good anchor after all. But it's Brexit and our intuitions might be challenged by the unbound creativity of the British parliamentary system. Now, resignation could be followed or not by a general election. This gives a large advantage to the conservative party regarding a potential new PM. If we assume a 50% chance of no election, we have a 5% probability of a new conservative PM. If there is an election, I will put the remaining 5% as 2% conservative, 2% labor, 1% other. Total: 7% conservative, 2% labor, 1% other. To do list: update from the inside view. Note to myself: check whether an update is required after the Queen's speech (14 October), EU council meeting (17-18 October) and Super Saturday / Doomsday Saturday (19 October).

There is so many possible outcomes here, its a very difficult question. My thoughts 1) For Boris not be PM we'd have to see one or more of the following
- he dies
- he resigns
- he loses election or vote of no confidence (very little time for an election to be called, and other parties unlikely to support it unless they see a realistic chance of winning, in which case Boris less likely to call it) The first couple of these are unlikely. Its possible that remain MPs could topple him in a vote of no confidence if they have no alternative to stop Brexit. Then we consider who would replace him
2) Labour (Corbyn) is the largest opposition party, but many rebel Tories and LibDems would find it difficult to back him. They may blink and do so, else they might urge some kind of leader for "national unity"
3) A leader that could appeal to remainers across parties could include a LibDem, a more moderate Labour candidate or a pro remain Conservative like Ken Clarke. Or it could include an Independent (quite a few now with MPs having quit or been pushed from both parties). I still think that the most likely scenario is that Boris stays after getting a (bad) deal, but its difficult to see how this one plays out in the case of no deal, or his deal being shot down by Parliament. There is one curve ball that we could see. Boris could be in legal trouble if it can be shown he handed out public money to his mistress while mayor of London. I imagine he'll double down, call it fake news, and refuse to co-operate, but British PMs don't have the same kind of protection that US Presidents have. At the very least he could be forced to resign.

The EU should think twice before rejecting Boris Johnson’s proposal Münchau (2019) October 6, states that: The member states of the EU have a common negotiating position on Brexit, but they have different ulterior motives. (Para. 1). There is one group, led by Germany, whose priority is to avoid a no-deal Brexit in order to minimize disruption to industrial supply chains. Another group, led by France, seeks to stop the UK from exploiting the opportunities for regulatory arbitrage. The French fear that a Singapore on Thames might undercut EU standards on social policy and the environment. Then there is a third group that wants the UK to reverse Brexit altogether, as a symbol of the fightback against the rising global tide of populism. What all three have in common is a lack of interest in agreeing to engage with UK prime minister Boris Johnson’s proposals for the withdrawal deal. They are reassured that the Brexit extension bill passed by the House of Commons has removed the threat of an immediate no-deal Brexit. Legal documents submitted to a Scottish court state that Mr Johnson intends to comply with the requirements of the Benn Act and seek a Brexit delay if he cannot secure a deal. But even if the deadline is extended once more, the EU should think twice before rejecting the latest UK plan. It is trivially true that an extension buys time, avoids disruption on the day, and maybe even opens up a theoretical path towards a Brexit reversal. But rejection would still be a short-sighted strategy. If the process is allowed to stray past the current October 31 deadline, the EU will have to live with the consequences of rejecting the deal (Para. 1-4). **

Since 1945, the base rate for a new PM is one every 4.5 years. Boris has been PM since the summer, so it would be highly unusual to see a change in PM so soon. It would be the shortest change since certainly since 1945 (starting from there as that is the modern era of politics, expanding the base rate past this is in my view unlikely to add any new information). To change a PM, the current PM has to resign, die, or lose the confidence of the House of Commons at which point a general election would USUALLY be held. However, since the introduction of the fixed terms parliaments act, a scenario in which a PM could take office without a dissolution of Parliament is now possible. But  although this is possible, it is unlikely given that such a scenario has not happened before. The new leader of a government in order to obtain an extension would be either from the Labour, Lib Dem parties or an Independent. As it currently stands, the Benn act compels the PM to ask for an extension if no deal is passed by the HoC. A deal could be passed in which the current PM would remain PM, as a coalition is not formed against him. There is the possibility that he resigns rather than ask for an extension, but the PM has the excuse that he was forced to do so by parliament or asks for an extension via another mechanism.  It seems like the most likely course of action that an extension is sought by some means, but then there is a general election, which could still happen by 2020 and change the PM. Given the polling numbers, I think that it is likely Boris remains PM.  This question is mainly tied up in what happens before the end of october, and there a lot of things that would have to happen for that to change, some of the highly unusual. I think that Boris will remain PM until the end of 2019.

Prime Minister Boris Johnson offers a new Brexit plan, new suspension of Parliament Adam, Birnbaum and Booth (2019) October 2, states that: LONDON — Prime Minister Boris Johnson bounced onto the stage at the annual Conservative Party conference in Manchester Wednesday and announced what he said were “constructive and reasonable proposals” for getting a Brexit deal done by the end of October. He was cheered in the conference hall. But his long-awaited written plan was met with raised eyebrows in Europe and roundly dismissed by opposition lawmakers in Britain. Johnson didn’t win any additional support when, hours later, his spokesman announced that the government would seek to suspend — or “prorogue” — Parliament from Oct. 8 through Oct. 14, when Queen Elizabeth II would come to the the chamber to deliver the “Queen’s Speech” and lay out a new agenda (Para. 1-3). In a letter to European President Jean-Claude Juncker detailing his new proposals Wednesday, Johnson reiterated his opposition to the Irish “backstop” — negotiated by his predecessor Theresa May to guarantee an open border on the island of Ireland. Johnson said his government was seeking a more decisive split from the European Union (Para. 5). “In these circumstances, the proposed ‘backstop’ is a bridge to nowhere, and a new way forward must be found,” he wrote (Para. 5-6).
The E.U. has in the past resisted such checks on the grounds that they could jeopardize the delicate peace established by the 1998 Good Friday agreement (Para. 8). [Within only one month, Boris Johnson lost control — and a historic Supreme Court battle] The proposals were not immediately rejected in Brussels or other European capitals, as has at times been the case following British negotiation gambits. Several analysts, though, said the prospect of a breakthrough didn’t look good. Johnson’s plan appears to cross red lines drawn years ago by European negotiators. Juncker cited “positive advances,” especially the proposal to keep many Northern Ireland regulations aligned with E.U. standards. But he said that there were “problematic points” related to Britain’s apparent unwillingness to commit to keeping the border fully and permanently open (Para. 8-11). ***__
